#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Cold as ice : Wikinews interviews Marymegan Daly on unusual new sea anemone
#Text=Tuesday , January 21 , 2014
#Text=How did you come to be involved with this discovery
#Text=Frank Rack got in touch after they returned from Antarctica in hopes that I could help with an identification on the anemone .
#Text=What was your first reaction upon learning there was an undiscovered ecosystem under the ice in the Ross Sea ?
#Text=I was amazed and really excited .
#Text=I think to say it was unexpected is inaccurate , because it implies that there was a well - founded expectation of something .

#Text=The technology that Frank and his colleagues are using to explore the ice is so important because , given our lack of data , we have no reasonable expectation of what it should be like , or what it should n't be like .
#Text=There 's a return trip planned hopefully for 2015 , with both biologists and ANDRILL geologists .
#Text=Are you intending to go there yourself ?
#Text=I would love to .
#Text=But I am also happy to not go , as long as someone collects more animals on my behalf !
#Text=What I want to do with the animals requires new material preserved in diverse ways , but it does n't require me to be there .

#Text=Although I am sure that being there would enhance my understanding of the animals and the system in which they live , and would help me formulate more and better questions about the anemones , ship time is expensive , especially in Antarctica , and if there are biologists whose contribution is predicated on being there , they should have priority to be there .
#Text=These animals are shrouded in mystery .
#Text=Some of the most intriguing questions are chemical ; do they produce some kind of antifreeze , and is that orange glow in the ROV lights their own ?
#Text=Talk us through the difficulties encountered when trying to find answers with the specimens on hand .
#Text=The samples we have are small in terms of numbers and they are all preserved in formalin ( a kind of formaldehyde solution ) .
#Text=The formalin is great for preserving structures , but for anemones , it prevents study of DNA or of the chemistry of the body .
#Text=This means we ca n't look at the issue you raise with these animals .

#Text=What we could do , however , was to study anatomy and figure out what it is , so that when we have samples preserved for studying e.g. , the genome , transcriptome , or metabolome , or conduct tests of the fluid in the burrows or in the animals themselves , we can make precise comparisons , and figure out what these animals have or do ( metabolically or chemically ) that lets them live where they live .

#Text=Just knowing a whole lot about a single species is n't very useful , even if that animal is as special as these clearly are - we need to know what about them is different and thus related to living in this strange way .
#Text=The only way to get at what 's different is to make comparisons with close relatives .
#Text=We can start that side of the work now , anticipating having more beasts in the future .
#Text=In terms of their glow , I suspect that it 's not theirs - although luminescence is common in anemone relatives , they do n't usually make light themselves .
#Text=They do make a host of florescent proteins , and these may interact with the light of the ROV to give that gorgeous glow .
#Text=What analysis did you perform on the specimens and what equipment was used ?
#Text=I used a dissecting scope to look at the animal 's external anatomy and overall body organization ( magnification of 60 X ) .

#Text=I embedded a few of the animals in wax and then cut them into very thin slices using a microtome , mounted the slices on microscope slides , stained the slices to enhance contrast , and then looked at those slides under a compound microscope
#Text=( that 's how I got the pictures of the muscles etc in the paper ) .
#Text=I used that same compound scope to look at squashed bits of tissue to see the stinging capsules ( = nematocysts ) .
#Text=I compared the things I saw under the 'scopes to what had been published on other species in this group .
#Text=This step seems trivial , but it is really the most important part !

#Text=By comparing my observations to what my colleagues and predecessors had found , I figured out what group it belongs to , and was able to determine that within that group , it was a new species .
#Text=It was three years between recovery of specimens and final publication , why did it take so long ?
#Text=You mean , how did we manage to make it all happen so quickly , right ? :)
#Text=It was about two years from when Frank sent me specimens to when we got the paper out .
#Text=Some of that time was just lost time - I had other projects in the queue that I needed to finish .

#Text=Once we figured out what it was , we played a lot of manuscript email tag , which can be challenging and time consuming given the differing schedules that folks keep in terms of travel , field work , etc.
#Text=Manuscript review and processing took about four months .
#Text=What sort of difficulties were posed by the unorthodox preservatives used , and what additional work might be possible on a specimen with intact DNA ?
#Text=The preservation was not unorthodox - they followed best practices for anatomical preservation .

#Text=Having DNA - suitable material will let us see whether there are new genes , or genes turned on in different ways and at different times that help explain how these animals burrow into hard ice and then survive in the cold .

#Text=I am curious about the population structure of the " fields " of anemones - the group to which Edwardsiella andrillae belongs includes many species that reproduce asexually , and it 's possible that the fields are " clones " produced asexually rather than the result of sexual reproduction .
#Text=DNA is the only way to test this .
#Text=This map shows the location of the Ross Ice Shelf in the Antarctic , and the two known localities for E. andrillae relative to McMurdo Station
#Text=image : Daily et al.
#Text=Daly explained how she obtained these images of the anemone 's anatomy .
#Text=Image : Daily et al.
